+error bar and false positive plots to ease the task of comparing light curve extractions
+from multiple apertures – no need to close two plots that are only needed for the final
+analysis.
+
+•
+
+Added a block of the most useful metrics for comparing light curve extractions from
+multiple apertures at the end of the text report window and also in the .log.txt report.
+
+•
+
+The metrics for each ‘solution’ are added to a text file (fit_metrics.txt) – this text file can
+be converted to a .xlsx file which can be used to support the choice of ‘solution’
+submitted in a report.
+
+•
+
+Changed snr to dnr (drop to noise ratio) in the places where that is the actual
+calculation being performed.

 • This version deals more realistically with high magDrop lightcurves by defining a
 'limiting magDrop' as:
 limMagDrop = 2.5 * log10( B / std(A) )
 std(A) is the noise level of A.
 B = average baseline intensity
 A = average event intensity
 Normally, we report/calculate magDrop = 2.5 * log10( B / A ), but this calculation becomes
@@ -894,16 +928,15 @@
 more and more as A approaches and then becomes smaller than std(A). For example, if A
 happened to be equal to std(A), the normal distribution of A values tells us that 84% of
 possible A values are > 0 and so can be used in the regular magDrop equation. The other
 16% of the time we can only report that the calculation could not be performed.
 The above observation suggests that reliable estimates of magDrop require that A be greater
 than std(A) --- that is the ad hoc reason that we have defined limMagDrop as we have.
 This value is substituted for a calculated magDrop whenever A is less than std(A), i.e.,
-
-whenever A is at or below std(A).
+whenever A is at or below std(A).
 limMagDrop values are reported with a leading > symbol to signify that that value is a
 limMagDrop value. They are easy to spot in the report.

+• Added additional tests of candidate solutions against a straight line so that there
